speaker: Neil
text: Hello. This is 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I’m Neil.

speaker: Sam
text: And I’m Sam.

speaker: Neil
text: People collect all kinds of things for a hobby, from stamps and coins to comics and football stickers. Do you collect anything, Sam?

speaker: Sam
text: I used to have a big collection of Pokémon cards but I have no idea where they are now.

speaker: collectablesnon-fungible
text: Well, maybe you should start looking for them because all kinds of collectables – that’s objects that people want to collect – are selling for big money on the internet. It’s all part of a new tech craze called non-fungible tokens, or NFTs for short.

speaker: Non-fungible
text: Non-fungible tokens?

speaker: Neil
text: Basically NTFs are unique, one-of-kind items that can be bought and sold like any physical object but only exist in the digital world. ‘Tokens’ can be thought of as certificates of ownership for these virtual possessions.

speaker: non-fungible
text: Hmmm, OK. I understand the ‘token’ part but what does ‘non-fungible’ mean?

speaker: fungible
text: If something is ‘fungible’ it can be interchanged, like money for example. With money you can swap a £10 note for two £5 notes and it will have the same value.

speaker: non-fungible
text: So, something non-fungible cannot be interchanged with something else. Is that because it has special features that make it unique?

speaker: Neil
text: Exactly. Imagine something totally unique like the Mona Lisa. You can take a photo of the painting or buy a copy of it, but there will only ever be the one original painting.

speaker: Sam
text: I can see that the Mona Lisa is one-of-a-kind and extremely valuable, but it’s not for sale on the internet!

speaker: Neil
text: True, but lots of other things are, from signed celebrity artwork to virtual football cards. NFTs are like autographed photos – collectors want something no-one else has, even though there’s nothing physical they actually own and keep.

speaker: Sam
text: And the value of NFTs is going up and up?

speaker: Neil
text: Massively. A digital sticker of French footballer, Kylian Mbappé, recently sold for £25,000! Which reminds me of my quiz question, Sam. In June 2021, Sir Tim Berners-Lee sold the original source code he used to invent the World Wide Web as an NFT at a charity auction. The sale started at $1000 but how much did the source code eventually sell for? Was it:

speaker: Neil
text: a) 5.4 thousand dollars?

speaker: Neil
text: b) 5.4 million dollars? or

speaker: Neil
text: c) 5.4 billion dollars?

speaker: Sam
text: If you’re asking me how much the internet sold for, I’d say c) 5.4 billion dollars.

speaker: Neil
text: OK, Sam, we’ll find out later if that’s right.

speaker: Sam
text: Sir Tim Berners-Lee famously never made any money from the World Wide Web, insisting that his invention should be free for everyone. But the world of NFTs is controversial and not everyone thinks Sir Tim should be getting involved.

speaker: Neil
text: That’s certainly the view of Shona Ghosh, technology editor at the ‘The Insider’ website, as she told BBC World Service programme, Tech Tent:

speaker: wild westroguecollectables
text: I think there’s a balance to be struck between exploring new technologies and Sir Tim Berners-Lee is an amazing figure but NFTs are a wild west. Not everything associated with NFTs are rogue, but these so-called digital collectables are going for lots of money.

speaker: wild west
text: Internet NFTs are very new and there are no rules controlling what can be sold and for how much, so Shona describes them as a wild west.

speaker: The Wild West
text: The Wild West means a situation where people can do whatever they want because there are no laws or controls, like the early history of the western part of the United States.

speaker: rogue
text: She also calls some things about NFTs rogue - behaving differently from what’s normal or expected, often in a way that causes damage.

speaker: Neil
text: Love them or hate them, there are strong opinions on both sides of the NFT debate, as Rory Cellan-Jones, presenter of BBC World Service’s Tech Tent, explains:

speaker: digital artefactspyramid scheme
text: To some NFTs are a brilliant innovation which has promised to put a value on digital artefacts. To others they’re little more than a dubious pyramid scheme with a damaging impact on the environment because of the way the tokens are created.

speaker: pyramid schemes
text: Some people are suspicious of the large amounts of money collectors are willing to pay, comparing NFTs to pyramid schemes - business tricks or scams where money is obtained dishonestly.

speaker: digital artefacts
text: But for others NFTs are a legitimate and useful way to put a price on rare digital artefacts – items, such as images, videos and music, that are produced and stored as electronic versions.

speaker: Sam
text: Items like, for example, the original source code for the internet. So how much money did Sir Tim Berners-Lee raise for charity when he sold it off, Neil?

speaker: Neil
text: In my quiz question I asked Sam how much the NFT of the original internet source code sold for at auction.

speaker: Sam
text: I said c) 5.4 billion dollars.

speaker: Neil
text: You were… wrong! In fact it was less - 5.4 million dollars – but still far too expensive for me to collect.

speaker: Sam
text: Hmmm, now I’m wondering how much my Pokémon card collection would sell for. If only I could find it!

speaker: digital artefacts
text: Well, while you look for your collection, Sam, let’s recap the vocabulary from this programme all about NFTs which are digital artefacts or items that are produced and stored as electronic versions.

speaker: collectables
text: NFTs are virtual collectables – desirable objects that people search for and collect.

speaker: non-fungible
text: And they are non-fungible meaning they have special and unique characteristics that cannot be interchanged with anything else.

speaker: rogue
text: If something is rogue it behaves in a different way from what’s normal or expected, often causing damage.

speaker: The wild west
text: The wild west describes a chaotic situation without laws or controls.

speaker: pyramid scheme
text: And finally, a pyramid scheme is a business scam where money is gained dishonestly.

speaker: non-fungible
text: If you’d like to know more about non-fungible tokens, bitcoin and other trending internet topics there’s plenty to find on the BBC website.

speaker: Sam
text: And for more interesting conversation and useful vocabulary, remember to join us again soon here at 6 Minute English. Bye for now!

speaker: Neil
text: Bye!
